entry.title: How I learned MEAN in a week!
entry.content:
I learned how to code in Angular when I was making a matrimony website for a project.

My dad gave me the job to create it and I accepted. Even though I was the one who was trying the website, my dad helped when I was stuck on something.

This way I learned MongoDB, ExpressJS, Angular and NodeJS, or MEAN. For the backend, I also tried Laravel PHP and MySQL, ExpressJS, and MySQL, but Laravel did not work when I tried to deploy it on AWS, and Express and MySQL are the worst combinations in this world!

Few years ago, my dad made a different website like when I was too little to code. That website was made so long ago that the Angular version it used was something like v4! So I had no choice but to convert it from v4 to v12 from scratch!

A lot of things went wrong; the routing was different and the sidebar in mobile view was ugly. The backend part was good, all the code in ExpressJS was clean.

The most exciting part was when I connected the domain with the AWS instance. That’s when I learned about nameservers. Anyway, I googled a lot about how to connect both of them, and I found Google telling me to add nameservers, so I reluctantly went to the AWS console and added nameservers. A few days later, when my dad tested the website and it worked! That was the most wonderful news for me!

And some days later when we launched it, dad bought all of us ice cream, even though my dad bought me ice cream a lot of time, it was wonderful!

The sad thing is the website failed, but I still learned a lot like, how to deploy to AWS, mainly what nameservers are.

So, the moral of the story is learn by doing!

BTW, if you are a Mac fanboy like me, You can enjoy MEAN stack a lot in Mac, I worked on my dad’s Mac and the specs were: MacBook Pro 15’ Retina Mid 2015 Version 10.15.3.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.summary: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.
entry.content:
Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.
